content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act to promote wildlife conservation on military reservations. Integrated natural resource management plans are required for military installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with the Secretary having the discretion to determine if a plan is not necessary for a specific installation. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, replacing "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the legislation. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, replacing "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the legislation. Amendments include changing references to "cooperative plans" to "integrated natural resource management plans" in various sections of the Act. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. This includes wetland protection and restoration, consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities, and the establishment of specific natural resource management goals and objectives. The legislation also removes references to "cooperative plans" and replaces them with "integrated natural resource management plans." The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. These plans address fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation. They ensure consistency among activities, no net loss in land capability for military missions, sustained public use of natural resources, and public access to the installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, ensuring public access to installations and professional enforcement of natural resource laws. Public comment is also required for each plan. SEC. 4. REVIEW OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS FOR INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. A report on these determinations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense, who will then report to Congress within 12 months. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not deemed appropriate, along with explanations for each. The deadline for these plans is 2 years after the report submission. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not appropriate. This plan should be mutually agreed upon by the Secretary of the Interior and the head of the State agencies, or negotiations should be completed for necessary changes to existing plans. Public comments must be allowed by the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Defense must allow public comments on proposed integrated natural resource management plans and changes to cooperative plans. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is amended to include subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect, expenditure on conservation efforts, and other relevant details. The Secretary of Defense must review and report on the implementation of natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report should include the number of plans in effect, conservation expenditure details, and compliance assessment with specific requirements to prevent land loss for military missions. The Secretary of Defense must annually submit a report by March 1 on conservation expenditures for natural resource management plans, in consultation with State agencies. The report is to be presented to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 6 amends Title I by allowing the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws related to natural resource conservation on military installations. SEC. 7 adds a new section for natural resource management services. SEC. 107 mandates that each military department must have trained personnel for natural resource management and law enforcement to comply with the Act. SEC. 8 adds definitions to Title I. The term 'military department' refers to the Department of the Army, Navy, and Air Force. 'Military installation' includes land owned by the US and managed by the Secretary of Defense or a military department. 'State fish and wildlife agency' is a state government agency responsible for managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'United States' refers to the States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories and possessions. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'." SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis". Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended to exclude section 1535 of that title. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed. SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections, including section 102 and section 103. Section 13 authorizes appropriations for programs on military installations and public lands for the years 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on September 12, 1994.
